chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: How should I manage acute HIV-related problems?
chapter.summary: Covers the management of acute HIV-related problems including when to admit, refer, or manage a person in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I admit a person with HIV?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange admission if:
    • The person is acutely unwell.
    • Respiratory symptoms are suggestive of a serious bacterial lower respiratory tract infection such as:
      • Pneumonia, or
      • Tuberculosis.
    • Visual symptoms are suggestive of a serious underlying condition such as cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis.
    • Progressive or acute neurological symptoms or delirium are present:
      • This may indicate a serious HIV-related condition such as cryptococcal meningitis, cerebral toxoplasmosis, or cerebral lymphoma.
    • Kaposi's sarcoma of the lung or gut is suspected — this can be life threatening.
    • Serious or life-threatening adverse effects of antiretroviral therapy are suspected, for example:
      • Drug hypersensitivity,
      • Lactic acidosis,
      • Liver toxicity,
      • Bone marrow suppression, or
      • Pancreatitis.
  • For further information on adverse effects and drug interactions see:
    • The British National Formulary (www.bnf.org).
    • The HIV drug interactions website (www.hiv-druginteractions.org).
  • If unsure whether the person needs to be admitted or not, discuss with a specialist.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the clinical guidance HIV in primary care. A practical guide for primary healthcare professionals in Europe [Matthews, 2016] and Guidelines for managing advanced HIV disease and rapid initiation of antiretroviral therapy [WHO, 2017], and expert opinion in a review article [BMJ Best Practice, 2018].

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer a person with HIV?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Refer (with urgency depending on the specific clinical situation) people presenting with:
    • Respiratory conditions:
      • Admission is indicated if pneumocystis pneumonia, tuberculosis, or atypical mycobacterium are suspected (even if the person is taking medication to prevent this).
      • Discuss with a specialist if unsure.
    • Gastrointestinal conditions:
      • Oesophageal candidiasis — refer to an HIV specialist.
      • Persistent diarrhoea — refer to an HIV specialist.
      • Viral hepatitis co-infection — refer to an HIV specialist.
    • Skin conditions:
      • Suspected Kaposi's sarcoma — refer to an HIV specialist.
    • Oral conditions:
      • Severe or resistant oral candidiasis — refer to an HIV specialist.
      • Gingivitis — refer to a dentist.
      • Dental abscess — refer to a dentist.
    • Genital conditions:
      • Genital and perianal warts — refer to a genito-urinary medicine (GUM) clinic. For further information, see the CKS topic on Warts - anogenital.
      • If there are any atypical features, refer under the 2 week rule for suspected cancer to a colorectal specialist — anal intra-epithelial and anal squamous cell carcinomas are more common in people with HIV.
      • Cervical screening — all women with newly diagnosed HIV should have initial colposcopy and annual cytology screening performed by or in conjunction with their HIV specialist team.
    • Sexual dysfunction:
      • Sexual problems such as erectile dysfunction and loss of libido should be thoroughly assessed — where appropriate refer to specialist services. For further information, see the CKS topic on Erectile dysfunction.
      • Be aware that some drug treatments commonly used to treat erectile dysfunction may interact with antiretroviral therapies (ART).
    • Mental health conditions:
      • Mental health conditions such as stress, anxiety, and depression should be assessed and managed as usual, referring to specialist mental health services where appropriate — some drug treatments may have serious interactions with ART, seek specialist advice before prescribing.
      • Nightmares, sleep disturbance, mood or behaviour changes, psychosis, and suicidal ideation have been reported as adverse effects of ART.
      • See the CKS topics on Generalized anxiety disorder and Depression for further information.
    • HIV-related cognitive impairment:
      • Refer to an HIV specialist.
  • If there is any uncertainty about whether to admit or the need to refer, discuss with an HIV specialist.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on clinical guidance HIV in primary care. A practical guide for primary healthcare professionals in Europe [Matthews, 2016], Consolidated guidelines on HIV prevention, diagnosis, treatment and care for key populations. 2016 update [WHO, 2016b], and BHIVA/BASHH/FSRH guidelines for the sexual & reproductive health of people living with HIV [BHIVA, 2017]; and expert opinion in review articles [BMJ Best Practice, 2018; Lebari, 2019].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Management in primary care
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If the person does not need to be admitted or referred and presents with:

  • A problem unrelated to HIV infection:
    • Management is, in general, as usual, but always check for potential drug interactions with antiretroviral therapy (ART) as these can be life threatening.
    • If unsure, check with the person’s HIV specialist.
  • A problem related to HIV infection (less likely to develop if a recent CD4 count is above 300 cells per microlitre and viral load is suppressed) such as:
    • Constitutional symptoms (such as flu-like symptoms, fever, weight loss, fatigue, and sweats):
      • Exclude serious causes such as opportunistic infections, chronic infections, and malignancies that need specialist management.
      • Urgent secondary care assessment may be indicated.
    • Skin conditions such as:
      • Fungal infections, see the CKS topics on Fungal nail infection, Fungal skin infection - body and groin, Fungal skin infection - foot, and Fungal skin infection - scalp. Prolonged or repeated courses of treatment may be needed.
      • Shingles and herpes simplex, see the CKS topics on Shingles, Herpes simplex - genital, and Herpes simplex - oral. Seek specialist advice if longer courses of treatment or higher doses are needed.
      • Warts and molluscum contagiosum, see the CKS topics on Warts and verrucae and Molluscum contagiosum.
      • Bacterial infections such as folliculitis and impetigo, see the CKS topics on Boils, carbuncles, and staphylococcal carriage and Impetigo.
      • Seborrhoeic dermatitis, see the CKS topic on Seborrhoeic dermatitis.
      • Psoriasis, see the CKS topic on Psoriasis.
    • Oral conditions such as:
      • Oral candida, see the CKS topic on Candida - oral. If severe, recurrent, or resistant to treatment, seek specialist advice.
      • Aphthous ulcers, see the CKS topic on Aphthous ulcer for further information. Seek specialist advice if resistant to treatment.
      • Gingivitis, see the CKS topic on Gingivitis and periodontitis.
      • Dental abscess, see the CKS topic on Dental abscess.
      • Oral hairy leukoplakia — discuss with the person’s HIV specialist, changes to ART may be indicated.
      • Kaposi’s sarcoma — seek urgent specialist advice.
    • Gastrointestinal conditions such as:
      • Nausea, consider adverse effects of ART — seek specialist advice if problematic.
      • Diarrhoea (which has a wide variety of causes including infection, adverse effects of ART, HIV in the intestinal mucosa, and pancreatic insufficiency) — arrange stool and other investigations as appropriate. Seek specialist advice if problematic or persistent.
    • Respiratory conditions:
      • Consider the need for admission.
      • Manage in primary care if the person is well and serious conditions such as pneumocystis pneumonia and tuberculosis have been excluded. See the CKS topics on Breathlessness, Cough, and Chest infections - adult for more information. Seek specialist advice if unsure.
    • Visual problems:
      • Have a low threshold for referral/seeking specialist advice if a person with HIV presents with visual symptoms (even if apparently minor, such as floaters) as this may indicate a serious condition such as cytomegalovirus retinitis.
    • Neurological problems:
      • Consider the need for admission or referral if the person presents with progressive or acute neurological problems.
      • Peripheral neuropathy — can be caused by ART or HIV infection. Seek specialist advice on management.
    • Genital conditions:
      • If severe, recurrent, or resistant to treatment, seek specialist advice.
      • For information on genital candida and genital herpes, see the CKS topics on Candida - female genital and Herpes simplex - genital.
    • Psychological conditions:
      • People living with HIV are at higher risk of depression, anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder, insomnia, addictions, and self-harm.
      • Be aware that some ART is associated with psychiatric disturbance and that some common drugs used to treat mental health conditions interact with ART — consider referral to specialist mental health services.
    • Metabolic abnormalities, cardiovascular disease, and age-related morbidities:
      • The risk of metabolic abnormalities (such as dyslipidaemia and insulin resistance) and cardiovascular disease is higher in people living with HIV — have a low threshold for investigation and seek specialist advice.
      • Other morbidities such as chronic kidney disease and low bone mineral density may be due to ART, lifestyle factors, and previous steroid treatment — seek specialist advice on management.
    • Sexual dysfunction:
      • Erectile dysfunction and loss of libido may be due to direct effects of HIV, psychological problems, ART, or vascular problems. Seek specialist advice.
  • A problem related to ART:
    • Check adherence to ART and ask about any adverse effects.
    • Check for drug interactions.
      • For further information see the British National Formulary (BNF) and check the HIV drug interactions website.
    • Discuss with the person's HIV specialist any concerns about potential adverse effects, poor adherence to ART or drug interactions.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on clinical guidance HIV in primary care. A practical guide for primary healthcare professionals in Europe [Matthews, 2016] and Standards of care for people living with HIV [BHIVA, 2018a], and expert opinion in review articles [Chu, 2017; Lebari, 2019].
